awd_titl_txt: Transforming fundamental biological questions about cell membranes into quantitative experiments using model and cell systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Mammals, including humans, are built out of cells. Mammalian cells are bounded by an outer membrane composed of lipids, cholesterol, and proteins. These three types of molecules are distributed nonuniformly across the cell's outer membrane, and this heterogeneity is reported to influence disease processes. However, scientists currently have little understanding of how this heterogeneity arises in cell membranes. This issue and a host of other fundamental questions about cell membranes are impractical to address in intact cells. As a result, this project will utilize simpler, tractable membrane systems. In the first case, membranes will be composed of only lipids and cholesterol. In the second case, membranes will be derived from mammalian cell outer membranes. In both cases, the membranes will be nonuniform. In this project, the researchers will conduct a series of experiments to understand the conditions under
which heterogeneity arises within lipid membranes. The long-­term goal of the project is to discover fundamental physical phenomena of lipid membranes that will subsequently prove applicable and relevant to biological cell membranes and to biotechnological applications. The researchers will convey the excitement and relevance of their results nationwide through press releases, public lectures, K-­12 outreach, and scientific journal articles. The principal investigator will train graduate students and undergraduates for careers in STEM fields and will mentor STEM faculty.

The behavior of membranes, even of relatively simple model membranes, is remarkably rich.This project will investigate membranes that segregate into domains enriched in specific lipid (and protein) types in both model lipid bilayers and in membranes derived from cell systems. The objective of the research is to understand what physical mechanisms render domains stable, what physical parameters distinguish domains from other membrane regions, and which structural features of lipids are required for domain formation. The research is question-­driven rather than technique-­driven; an array of tools will be deployed including imaging of membranes on solid supports by atomic force microscopy and imaging of free-­floating vesicles by fluorescence microscopy.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Our research group investigates membranes in living cells and in artificial systems. In particular, we investigate phase separation of membranes, which is an important biological problem with many applications. For example, in yeast, membrane phase separation is required for the long-term survival of the cell after periods of nutrient depletion.

 

The intellectual merit of our research during this award lies in our scientific discoveries and our advancement of new methods. Some highlights of our project’s intellectual merit are below.

 

• In 2015, we made a measurement that was the first of its kind. Specifically, we quantified a parameter that determines how the strongly the two sides of a membrane interact. Our findings are important to the physics community because several theories depend on the parameter. Before our measurement, the theorists had to consider values spanning nearly a factor of 100. Our findings are also important to the biology community. Biologists had previously hypothesized that proteins on different sides of a membrane could be coupled via the lipids in a membrane, but had no quantitative means to assess if their hypotheses were feasible. Our resulting article was published as the cover of the Biophysical Journal.

• In 2016, we measured the rate at which cholesterol is pulled from lipid bilayers. The reason that our measurement is important is it may relate to how cells regulate the cholesterol composition in their outer membrane. We published our results in the Biophysical Journal.

• In 2017, we showed that micron-scale domains in membranes in yeast vacuoles are due to reversible phase separation of their membranes, and published our article in the Biophysical Journal. Our results are impactful because controversy has long surrounded the question of whether phase separation of membranes into liquid phases can organize proteins and lipids on micron scales in unperturbed, living cells. Our results were of such broad interest to the scientific community that Physics Today wrote a 3-page article highlighting our research project and our laboratory.

• In 2020, we validated a new cryo-electron microscopic method of identifying coexisting liquid domains in membranes, which was published as the cover of the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Our advance makes it possible for future researchers to ask new questions that harness the very high resolution of cryo electron microscopy.

• In 2021, we will again publish our results in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. In our manuscript (which is currently accepted for publication by the journal), we showed that a particular solvent (1,6-hexanediol) does not disrupt model membranes at low concentrations. Our result is significant because researchers world-wide commonly use 1,6-hexanediol to disrupt phase separation of proteins in the cytoplasm of cells.

 

Broader impacts of our research include dissemination of our results through the publications listed above, direct dissemination of original computer code, and scientific outreach to school children, college students, and the general public. Some highlights of our broader impacts are below.

 

• We wrote original code to analyzed images of lipid bilayers collected by cryo electron tomography. We made our code available by public license at github. We also wrote original code to analyze patterns in membranes imaged by fluorescence microscopy. We published our full code as supplementary material with a journal article.

• To engage K-12 students, we volunteered for a “Meet the Scientist” event at a local elementary school, volunteered at an elementary school to challenge stereotypes of what scientists look like, participated in the “Meet-a-Scientist” program at the Pacific Science Center, conducted chemistry demonstrations at the Pacific Science Center, mentored high school students through science projects spanning an academic year, and judged science fairs for Seattle Public Schools.

• To engage college students, we gave presentations geared to low-income college students, who are typically underrepresented in science. We wrote articles for chembites.org, which is a website with the goal of communicating the excitement and results of primary scientific literature to high school and undergraduate students nationally.

• We recorded a tutorial on the basics of phase separation through the Biophysics and Physical Biology Seminar, which is archived on YouTube. This tutorial was designed to improve the training of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs who are investigating systems that undergo phase separation into two liquid phases, whether or not those systems are in lipid membranes.

• To help early-career researchers form peer mentoring groups, we hosted an international co-mentoring discussion and shared tips for maintaining laboratory productivity and morale during the COVID-19 pandemic.

• We participated in a Wikipedia edit-a-thon and improved existing Wikipedia pages in order to explain the discoveries and impact of scientists to the general public.

 

In conclusion, the activities funded by this grant have had far-reaching impact within the scientific community and beyond, into the broader community, both locally and nationally.


Last Modified: 11/15/2021
Modified by: Sarah L Keller

Image
  • The image shows individual, heart-shaped membranes deposited on a glass surface. The areas of these membranes were analyzed to determine the rate at which cholesterol is depleted from membranes of various compositions. The results were published in the Biophysical Journal in 2016 (110:635-645).
